President GEORGE W.
BUSH: I call on Congress to reauthorize the 16 critical provisions of this act that are scheduled to expire at the end of this year.

Joining us for a look ahead at the week in Washington is NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving.
Ron, the Patriot Act has been a cause of controversy practically since it was enacted right after the terror attacks of 9/11.
What are the politics of the issue now?
Different from what they were a week ago, Alex.
Before these London bombings, a lot of the talk in Congress was about letting some of these provisions expire; not all 16, of course, that the president was referring to, but a few.
And I think some still may, but the administration clearly has a new pressure point here in these London attacks.

And one of the best intelligence systems in the world in Great Britain was apparently caught flat-footed by these attacks, and the emphasis of the moment is going to be on new means of gathering intelligence to prevent such attacks in the future, and including in this country.
So when is the full Congress going to act on these proposals?
It will take some months before Congress finishes its work on this, but we have a critical moment in the process this week.
On Wednesday, the House Judiciary Committee is going to mark up a bill that promises to be a good deal stronger than what might have been contemplated even a week ago.
